pageContext.title: 10 Chinese tech companies that everyone will be talking about in 2019
pageContext.content:
Between 2012 and 2017, China has produced 46 unicorns, showing that it’s a serious contender as the next global tech leader.

Its startup ecosystem keeps investors active, dominating global venture capital filings and boasting mergers, acquisitions, and initial public offerings.

Using Tech in Asia’s database of investment deals – mostly based on funding rounds and acquisitions that have been covered by media – here’s a list of 10 Chinese tech companies to watch in 2019, ranked according to the amount of funding they’ve received or have been acquired for, this year.

1. Mobike

Photo credit: Mobike

Founded in 2015, Mobike is a bike-sharing startup that operates in more than 200 cities worldwide. Its rapid rise has been marked by user problems, including violations of bike-parking rules.

Meituan-Dianping acquired Mobike for US$2.7 billion in April 2018, and the ecommerce company subsequently removed the user deposit requirement, which was meant to incentivize good behavior.

In September this year, Meituan-Dianping debuted on the Hong Kong stock market, raising US$4.2 billion from investors. How this IPO will affect Mobike and arm it against competitors remains to be seen.

2. Pinduoduo

Photo credit: Pinduoduo

Ecommerce platform Pinduoduo, which allows users to join group-buying deals, went from startup to Nasdaq-listed company in just three years. It raised US$1.6 billion in its July 2018 IPO, gaining a valuation of US$24 billion.

In its IPO prospectus, Pinduouduo reportedly described itself as a combination of Disneyland and American warehouse club Costco. In other words, the company is positioning itself as a provider of both entertainment and value-for-money products. It also aims to gain a larger market share than Alibaba and JD.

3. JD Logistics

Photo credit: JD.com

JD Logistics, a business unit of JD, offers supply chain solutions like warehousing, transportation, and order delivery for ecommerce companies. In February 2018, it raised US$2.5 billion in funding from investors China Development Bank, China Life Insurance, China Merchants Capital, China Renaissance, Hillhouse Capital, ICBC International, Sequoia Capital, and Tencent.

JD Logistics aims to build a “smart” supply chain value network with industry partners and to play a key role in China’s ecommerce infrastructure. Last year, it opened a fully automated B2C warehouse just outside Shanghai – said to be the world’s first – and is researching the use of autonomous light electric delivery vans.

4. Manbang

Photo credit: PublicDomainPictures.net

Manbang is a Chinese truck-hailing firm and has been called an “Uber for trucks.” It was formed in 2017 by a merger between logistics companies Yunmanman and Huochebang.

In April 2018, it raised late-stage funding of US$1.9 billion, led by China Reform Management and SoftBank Vision Fund.

Manbang has invested research and development funds into new energy, intelligent driving, and other emerging areas to improve the logistics infrastructure in China.

5. Unicloud

Photo credit: Jeferrb

Unicloud provides its users with IT investment, financing, construction, and operation services. In July, the startup received US$1.74 million in strategic investment from Tsinghua Unigroup.

6. Ping An Good Doctor

Photo credit: Ping An Good Doctor

The medical industry in China has caught up with the online-to-offline (O2O) strategy now widely embraced by the country’s ecommerce players. Ping An Good Doctor, for instance, is a one-stop health management app that operates via a unique model combining an AI physician, a full-time medical team, and external resources. It also provides health, automobile, accident, property, and life insurance products to individuals and organizations.

Early this year, Ping An Good Doctor raised US$1.5 million from SoftBank China Capital. In August, it signed a joint venture with Grab to extend its services to Southeast Asian customers. It also announced an AI-driven “smart listening diagnosis” platform that provides health advice based on traditional Chinese medicine – a first in China.

7. ZTO Express

Photo credit: ZTO Express

ZTO Express provides fast delivery for online merchants, including top Chinese ecommerce platforms Alibaba and JD. Alibaba Group and its Cainiao Logistics unit led the startup’s latest funding round of US$1.38 billion – an investment that will help the company expand its network globally.

8. Didi Chuxing

Didi’s president, Jean Liu, onstage at WSJDLive in Laguna, California / Image credit: Wall Street Journal

Since it began operations in 2012, Didi Chuxing has gained more than 550 million users in over 400 cities, mostly in China.

With an eye on globalization, Didi has also expanded to Australia, Brazil, Japan, and Mexico. In July, it raised late-stage funding of US$500 million from Booking Holdings, an online travel platform.

9. SouChe

Image credit: Pixabay

SouChe boasts an intelligent system that matches buyers with sellers of both new and used cars. In its latest funding round, it received US$578 million from a group of six investors led by Morningside Venture Capital and Primavera Capital Group.

There have been rumors about SouChe filing for an IPO in the US ever since it raised raised US$335 million in an Alibaba-led funding round. It’s also investing in data analytics to leverage data from the Chinese auto industry – a sound move given SouChe’s entry into auto financing.

10. Youxia Motors

Photo credit: Youxia

A distributor and manufacturer of electric vehicles and equipment, the company aims to begin mass production by the end of 2019. Youxia Motors is constructing a factory that will eventually be capable of producing 200,000 units annually.

Last August, Youxia raised US$350 million in a series B round by Ghezi Asset Management.

seo.title: 10 Chinese tech companies poised to breakout in 2019
seo.description: They’re ranked according to the amount of funding they’ve received this year – or their purchase price.
